69 percent of mail voters across the nation returned their ballots via the U.S. Postal Service. 29 percent returned them in person to an official election location such as a polling place, early voting center or drop box. 85 percent returned their ballots themselves, and 14 percent gave their ballots to someone else to mail or drop off for them.
Given that nearly three in 10 voters returned mail ballots — and that all voting is done by mail in states such as Oregon and Washington, and state such as Arizona and Colorado allow voters to register as permanent mail voters — Becker said election officials need to have the infrastructure in place to accept ballots delivered in person.
